questions.text: 1. Cancer cells consume more glucose by which of the following process?

choices.text: Increased lactate is produced even in the presence of oxygen
Increased conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA

questions.solution:
In cancer cells, increased lactate is produced even in the presence of oxygen which is known as the Warburg Effect.

Neoplastic cells utilize Warburg metabolism for the generation of metabolic intermediates, which are needed for cell growth and multiplication. The Warburg Effect is a phenomenon in which there is an increase in the rate of glucose uptake and conversion into lactate(fermentation), even in the presence of oxygen. Cancer cells derive energy mainly from glycolysis. 

Cancer cells utilize glycolysis (2 ATP) over mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (36 ATP) for glucose metabolism, even though the latter produces more ATP. It is because pure oxidative phosphorylation produces abundant ATP, but also burns glucose to CO2 and H2O, leaving no carbon moieties suitable for use as building blocks for lipids or proteins.

For this reason, rapidly growing cells, by undergoing glycolysis, produce carbon moieties that are needed for growth and cellular maintenance.

The image given below shows the comparison of glucose metabolism in normal cells versus cancer cells.



As a result of decreased ATP production, the main metabolic function of mitochondria in growing cells is not to generate ATP, but to carry out reactions that generate cellular building blocks. For example, lipid biosynthesis.

Warburg effect is produced by growth factor receptors downstream signalling pathways. These include receptor tyrosine kinase/PI3K/AKT and MYC.

Clinically, cancer cells exhibiting the Warburg effect show a property of glucose hunger. This is used to visualize them via positron emission tomography (PET) scanning.

questions.text:
2. In Glucose 6-Phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, what will be the bilirubin finding?

Options Direct bilirubin Indirect bilirubin Urine urobilinogen
1 Normal Increased Increased
2 Increased Normal Absent
3 Normal Normal Normal
4 Decreased Decreased Increased
questions.solution:
In Glucose 6-Phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, direct bilirubin is normal, indirect bilirubin is increased and urine urobilinogen is increased. 

Glucose 6-Phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme that plays a critical role in redox reactions that occur in all aerobic cells. It is the only source of NADPH in erythrocytes that helps in the formation of reduced glutathione. This reduced form protects erythrocytes against oxidative stress. Glucose 6-Phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is an X-linked inheritance disorder. Most patients with this condition are asymptomatic. But when exposed to oxidative triggers, they are prone to develop acute hemolytic anemia. The various oxidative triggers include:

* Fava beans

* Infections

* Drugs such as primaquine, chloroquine, sulfonamides/sulfones, dapsone, and nitrofurantoin

Bilirubin is the breakdown product of heme metabolism which is formed in the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver. It is insoluble in water and is known as unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. In hemolytic anemia, liver function tests will reveal an elevated indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin because excess hemoglobin from RBCs is converted to bilirubin. The increased production of bilirubin leads to increased production of urobilinogen, which appears in the urine in large amounts. Bilirubin is not usually found in the urine in hemolytic jaundice, so the combination of increased urobilinogen and absence of bilirubin in urine is suggestive of hemolytic jaundice.

questions.text: 3. Cyanide and carbon monoxide act on which of the Heme proteins:
questions.solution:
Cyanide and carbon monoxide act on Cytochrome c oxidase . 

Carbon monoxide binds to the heme iron of cytochrome c oxidase in its reduced (ferrous, Fe²⁺) state. This prevents oxygen from binding and accepting electrons, halting the production of water and the proton gradient. Poisoning with CO can lead to severe hypoxia at the cellular level, even in the presence of normal oxygen levels.

Cyanide binds irreversibly to the ferric (Fe³⁺) iron in the heme group of cytochrome c oxidase. It completely blocks electron transfer to oxygen, making it a potent inhibitor. Cyanide poisoning results in rapid cellular asphyxiation and is life-threatening. 

Cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) in the electron transport chain (ETC) is the terminal enzyme that facilitates the transfer of electrons to molecular oxygen, reducing it to water. Various inhibitors can block this process, leading to impaired oxidative phosphorylation and ATP synthesis including hydrogen sulfide which inhibits Complex IV at high concentrations by binding to its heme groups, similar to cyanide. Its inhibition is dose-dependent, but it remains a strong inhibitor at high levels.

Pearl PM0078: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text:
4. In the glycine titration curve, find the zwitter bionic pH:

pK1 = 2.4 pK2 = 9.8
questions.solution:
The zwitter bionic pH of glycine is 6.

The zwitter bionic pH, also known as the isoelectric point (pI), is the pH at which an amino acid carries no net electrical charge. At this point, the molecule exists as a zwitterion - a form that has equal positive and negative charges, typically with a protonated amino group (-NH₃⁺) and a deprotonated carboxyl group (-COO⁻).

For simple amino acids like glycine, which have only two ionizable groups (carboxyl and amino), the isoelectric point is calculated as the average of the two pKa values:

pI = ( pK1 ​+pK2 ) / 2

​​Given:

pK1 = 2.4 (carboxyl group) pK2 = 9.8 (amino group)

pI = (2.4+9.8) / 2 = 12.2/2 = 6.1, which is closest to 6 (Option A).

At pH 6.1, glycine is in its zwitter bionic form and has no net charge.

questions.text:
5. An obese individual with a weight of 90kg takes a high-carbohydrate diet . Which enzymes are most responsible for weight gain?

* Malonyl-CoA

* Acetyl-CoA carboxylase

* Mitochondrial Carnitine transporter

* Tricarboxylate transporter
questions.solution:
The enzymes responsible for weight gain in this patient are Malonyl-CoA, Acetyl CoA carboxylase and Tricarboxylate transporter (Options 1, 2, 4). 

An obese individual on a high-carbohydrate diet will experience increased lipogenesis (fat synthesis) which would involve the following enzymes: 

* Malonyl-CoA: The initial step in fatty acid synthesis is the carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to form malonyl-CoA by acetyl-CoA carboxylase. It is a key intermediate in fatty acid synthesis.

* Acetyl-CoA carboxylase: It is the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid synthesis. It converts acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, thus promoting lipogenesis.

* Tricarboxylate transporter: It transports citrate from mitochondria to cytoplasm. In the cytoplasm, citrate is cleaved to oxaloacetate and acetyl CoA by the enzyme, ATP citrate lyase.

Mitochondrial carnitine transporter is involved in fatty acid oxidation, not synthesis. It helps transport fatty acids into mitochondria for breakdown. Its role is reduced, not promoted, in weight gain.

Pearl PM0638: Biosynthesis of Fatty acids

questions.text: 6. How many cycles of PCR is required to generate half the copies of 26 cycles?
questions.solution:
25 cycles of PCR is required to generate half the copies of 26 cycles. 

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a method used to amplify specific DNA sequences. It involves repeated cycles of denaturation, annealing, and extension. In each cycle, the amount of DNA doubles, leading to exponential amplification.

So after n cycles, the number of DNA copies is 2n . 

After 26 cycles, the DNA is amplified to 226 copies. To find how many cycles are needed to produce half this amount (x), 

2x = 1/2 × 226 =225 

So, x = 25. Therefore, 25 cycles are required to produce half as many DNA copies as 26 cycles.

PCR’s rapid and specific amplification relies on heat-stable DNA polymerases and specific primers that flank the target DNA sequence. Its applications include genetic diagnostics, forensic testing, and infectious disease detection.

questions.text: 7. A neonate was normal at birth but developed liver disease and muscle weakness 4 months later. She had severe hypoglycemia particularly in the morning after an overnight fast. On examination, there is hepatomegaly. Lab tests done after fasting show ketoacidosis, pH 7.25, increased ALT and AST levels. On administering IV glucagon after a carbohydrate meal, a normal rise in blood glucose levels is seen whereas on giving IV glucagon after an overnight fast, no rise on blood glucose levels is seen. Liver biopsy shows increased glycogen (8% of weight). Which enzyme has a defect?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Cori's disease which has a defect of debranching enzyme. A key diagnostic clue is the liver biopsy showing increased glycogen content (8% of liver weight), indicating that glycogen is being stored but not effectively broken down. Importantly, the IV glucagon test showed a rise in blood glucose after a carbohydrate meal, but no rise after an overnight fast - this suggests that glycogen is present in the liver but cannot be fully mobilized during fasting.

Glycogen debranching enzyme deficiency (glycogen storage disease III) is also known as Cori's disease, Forbes' disease, and limit dextrinosis. The debranching enzyme, together with phosphorylase, is responsible for the complete degradation of glycogen. In this case, the debranching enzyme is defective; hence, the glycogen breakdown is incomplete, which results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer-branch chains, which resemble limit dextrin.

Cori’s disease can present with fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and growth retardation. Muscle weakness is slowly progressive and associated with wasting. Accumulation of limit dextrins is seen in Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through enzyme assays in the liver, muscle, or both.

The purpose of the glucagon challenge test is to help differentiate types of glycogen storage diseases (GSDs), particularly Von Gierke’s disease (Type I) and Cori’s disease (Type III). When glucagon is given after a carbohydrate meal, a normal rise in blood glucose occurs in Cori’s disease, because some glycogen is still accessible for breakdown. However, after prolonged fasting, glucagon does not raise blood glucose in either Von Gierke's or Cori’s disease. In Von Gierke’s, glucose-6-phosphatase is defective, so no glucose is released at all, even after feeding.

Condition Glucagon after meal Glucagon after fast
Normal individual Normal rise in blood glucose Normal rise in blood glucose
Von Gierke’s disease No rise in blood glucose No rise in blood glucose
Cori’s disease Normal rise in blood glucose No rise in blood glucose


Other options:

Option B: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease) affects only skeletal muscle, causing exercise-induced cramps and weakness. Muscle glycogen is abnormally high and blood lactate is low after exercise. It does not cause hypoglycemia or liver enlargement, so it doesn't fit this case.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (Von Gierke disease) causes severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and ketosis. There is no glucose rise even after a meal, unlike in this patient.

Option D: Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (Hers disease) results in mild hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly but typically spares muscle and has milder symptoms. Muscle weakness and severe fasting symptoms are uncommon.

questions.text: 8. Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: Northern blotting - RNA, Southern blotting - Protein, Western blotting - DNA
Northern blotting - DNA, Southern blotting -  RNA , Western blotting - Protein
Northern blotting - DNA, Southern blotting - Protein, Western blotting - RNA
Northern blotting - RNA, Southern blotting - DNA, Western blotting  - Protein

questions.solution:
The test samples in northern, southern, and western blot tests are RNA, DNA, and protein, respectively. Hence, the correct answer is Northern blotting - RNA, Southern blotting - DNA, Western blotting  - Protein. 

Blot transfer tests are of three types based on the sample being tested and the probes used. Here is a table summarizing the test samples and probes used in the blot transfer test.

  Northern blot Southern blot Western blot
Test sample RNA DNA Protein
Probe  cDNA cDNA Antibody


 

The common step between them is transferring the separated fragments onto a specific blotting paper after gel electrophoresis. The probe is then added, and it binds to complementary fragments, which are then detected by specific methods like X-ray imaging or autoradiography.

questions.text: 9. Gene pool refers to all the alleles in ________
questions.solution:
Gene pool refers to all the alleles in population. 

Gene pool is defined as the total genetic information present in all the breeding individuals of that population. This concept is central to sexually reproducing species, where individuals interbreed and share genetic material. The gene pool changes over time due to mutations, natural selection, genetic drift, and gene flow between populations. It reflects the overall genetic diversity and evolutionary potential of a population.

questions.text: 10. A 4 year old child presents with developmental regression, hepatomegaly, and a cherry-red spot in the macula. The startle reflex is normal. Which of the following lysosomal enzymes is deficient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of developmental regression along with hepatomegaly, macular cherry-red spot, and normal startle reflex point to a diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease. The enzyme deficient in this disease is sphingomyelinase.

Niemann-Pick disease presents in infancy and usually leads to death by 2-3 years of age. The affected infants are normal at birth, but deteriorate rapidly with failure to thrive. The usual clinical presentation includes hepatosplenomegaly and rapid psychomotor retardation.

Niemann-Pick disease occurs due to the deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase enzyme. There is an extensive accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. Lipid-laden foam cells are observed in bone marrow and lymph nodes. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the sphingomyelinase levels in the peripheral leucocytes. 

This condition is managed with supportive treatment, such as physical therapy and a feeding tube for nutrition. Olipudase alfa has been recently approved for non-CNS manifestations of Niemann-Pick disease. 

Other options:

Option B: Hexosaminidase A deficiency is seen in Tay-Sachs disease. While it also presents with progressive neurodegeneration and macular cherry-red spot, there is no organomegaly and lysosomes with onion skin are seen. Startle reflex is exaggerated in Tay-Sachs disease. 

Option C: Glucocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease. The patients present with hematological abnormalities, organomegaly, and skeletal manifestations in the form of bone pain and pathological fractures. Bone marrow examination shows macrophages with a characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance.

Option D: Arylsulfatase A deficiency is seen in Metachromatic leukodystrophy. It primarily causes demyelination and psychological disturbances, and does not present with hepatomegaly or a cherry-red macula.
